transcripts.text: For NYUp and Syracuse.com, this is Matt Perino, joined as always by Ryan Talbot.  And we have entered Phase 3 of off-season workouts.  OTAs begin this week, and the first practice will be open to the media on Tuesday.  And Ryan put out... Monday, eight big questions that are facing the Bills heading into OTAs.  I put some of the top position battles and we thought, let's connect, talk about some of the things we're looking forward to in OTAs as we progress through this offseason in anticipation for the 2019 NFL season.  And Ryan, first and foremost, I think that it all comes back to Josh Allen.  We talked about it over and over again throughout the off season, you know, Brandon being putting pieces around Josh Allen.  And this is going to be the first look that we get at Josh Allen with all of these new toys.

Yeah, absolutely.  Obviously the wide receivers that they added, John Brown, a guy that can provide that speed on the outside across from Robert Foster, Cole Beasley in the slot, maybe even Andre Robertson in a smaller role in the receiving game, more so special teams there.  Duke Williams, a guy that I think a lot of fans are interested to see what he can do just because The Bills are very aggressive to add him early in free agency, the top CFL wide receiver in 2018.  And that also leads to the offensive line and the guys that are going to be protecting him this season and then.

Yeah, definitely.  And, you know, with Josh Allen, I think that we saw what he was able to do with a few of these guys last year.  Foster and Zay Jones, Isaiah McKenzie, who's going to be battling for a position or for a roster spot in camp.  And some of these some of these names at the bottom of the wide receiver depth chart, you're not right.  Probably aren't getting too many headlines right now, but you look at a guy like Cam Phillips, who at times really impressed in preseason training camp last year.  He's obviously made it to a second go-around with the Bills, and there's not a lot of wiggle room, but some of these lower caliber names are people... and players to keep an eye on.  And then you look at the tight end position in particular, obviously a whole new group aside from Jason Kroon in the room with Josh Allen.  And, you know, it's going to be interesting to chronicle how the, you know, progressions are made specifically with the rookies, Tommy Sweeney, 7th round, and... This marquee draft pick, trading back up into the third to get Dawson Knox.  I think it's going to be interesting to see how they're all utilized and how they all assimilate into the Bills system.  That's one thing that Sean McDermott has been talking about for the past few weeks.  is it's now on him.  He's going to take the reins from Brandon Bean and try to meld everything together on the offensive side.  Obviously, Brian Dable is going to have a big piece in that.

Yeah, without a doubt.  And just like the wide receiver position, there's very little wiggle room in the tight end room.  Obviously, Dawson Knox, early draft pick, round three pick, he's going to be a guy that makes the roster.  You think based on the contract that just gave Lee Smith, he's going to be there.  blocking tight end.  and obviously tyler croft was a guy that they signed early in free agency to a sizable deal.  so there's three right there.  and then like you said is it going to be tommy sweeney?  is it going to be jason croon?  will they even carry four tight ends?  so very little wiggle room there.  and this is their first chance for some of these players to kind of uh show show the team what they can do and show that they belong on this roster.

Ed Oliver, back at minicamp, looked the part amongst tryout players, majority of tryout players.  I mean, he really stood out.  And this is going to be the first time we get a look at him with NFL caliber players.  I mean, on that defensive line with Starlo Tulule, Harrison Phillips, and then on the outside, some of the different pass rushers.  It's going to be interesting to see because obviously there's not any pads, there's not going to be any hitting, but the athleticism that's been talked about with Ed Oliver is something that I think in these kind of drills, those kind of trades could really pop.

Yeah, and he's going to be playing in a position that's better suited for his skill set at the 3-tech, where Houston has been playing him at the 0-tech the last few years.  So it's also going to be one of those things where his athleticism, he's going to be able to show that off to the Bills as soon as OTAs.  Like you said, there's no pads or anything at this point, but still fans are going to be excited to hear what the media thinks about Ed Oliver tomorrow and how he looks compared to other NFL players.

We put out the position battles to kind of monitor for fans, and the real meat of that isn't going to start until training camp.  But I think it's going to be very interesting to see what our starting point is.  You figure the team is committed to Deion Dawkins at that left tackle spot.  They've said it a few times, so I anticipate seeing him there.  as the day one starter.  But then it gets very interesting because you have so many different elements in play.  You have a swing tackle, Ty Insecchi, who was paid a considerable amount of money for a guy that's been, for the majority of his career, a backup in the NFL.  And then you have second-round draft pick Cody Ford, who Brandon Bede came out and, you know, said that the team sees him as a right tackle.  And, you know, you spend a draft pick on a guy like that, and you hope that he's a contributor from day one.  And I think that, you know, if Deion Dawkins is on the left and Cody Ford is on the right, it's very interesting to see what they're going to do with Ty Insecchi because I think a lot of people believe whichever side he ends up on, he's going to be a starter on this team.

Yeah, offensive line is the thing that's most interesting to me, just because there's so many jobs that are up for grabs, and we really don't know how it's all going to shake out.  Mitch Morse, obviously, will be the opening day starter at center.  I feel good about Deion Dawkins probably being in play at left tackle as well.  If he struggles in training camp, if he struggles this summer, maybe they do say, well, listen, you know, Ty Insecchi has had some experience at left tackle at Washington.  Let's try him out there.  And if he outperforms him, maybe you put Insecchi there and you play for it.  at right tackle and it's not just the starting offensive line it's how is the depth going to shake out too

Yeah, you know, I still think Levi Wallace will end up getting that job.  I think that he showed over those last seven games that he belonged, that he could hold his own because he was tested. Yeah, you know, nationally, no one was really talking about Matt Milano last year, but I thought he was playing at a Pro Bowl level for Buffalo.  I just feel like he was a guy that was flying around the field.  Anytime that you saw a play, he was somewhere in that screenshot.  He was seldom out of place last year. With Josh Allen, one of the things that I was really interested to watch back at rookie minicamp was our first look at, you know, new positional coaches, you know, Bobby Johnson, quarterbacks coach.
